commentBody:
Christina often answers questions in the Easy Mode email.  I thought people who don't get that would be interested in this week's Q & A.

How constructors handle archaic and obscure entries
By Christina Iverson

‚ÄúOften I find that the puzzle ends in an exceptionally challenging area with more than a few words that are either a real stretch, rarely used or archaic. I wonder if the puzzle maker struggled with that particular area when the puzzle was under construction, and that same area is where they ended. Do you think this is true?‚Äù ‚Äî Anonymous

From Christina:

When constructors start making a puzzle, they generally start with a ‚Äúgrid skeleton,‚Äù which is just the black squares placed strategically around the theme entries. With a solid skeleton, there are nearly endless possibilities for what words you can use to fill the rest of the grid. The constructor will typically try to start filling the grid in the most constrained area ‚Äî long entries that cross several theme entries, perhaps, or an unusual pattern like a five-letter entry that ends in V.

For a themeless puzzle, the grid skeleton may or may not have certain entries locked in. Some constructors start with one or more ‚Äúseed entries,‚Äù which are words or phrases that they‚Äôd like to build a puzzle around. Other themeless constructors start with a particular grid design that they find appealing, without any entries locked in place.

Some of our correspondents will feel like 50A is like pouring salt into a fresh wound.  Even though this isn't the LA Times.

It was, though, probably the best World Series of this century, so far.
DERMA is on the MENU again?
This was such an enjoyable solve!
Pleasant puzzle with a quartet of fun expressions.  STILLMOOING was new to me, and SADTROMBONE, always gives me a smile.  I would have liked a little more resistance.

Come on, derma again? At least put (obsolete) or (var). Or clue it in a way that makes sense. 

What about ‚Äúskin opening?‚Äù
Challenging, despite the fact that it wasn‚Äôt one of those mind breaking 45-minute jobs.

I found this to be one of the easiest Saturday puzzles in recent memory.  I finished it 44.2% faster than my Saturday average.

My biggest difficulty was figuring out where to put the H in WELL LA DI DAH.  And having gotten that, wondering, like Caitlin did, if it was wrong because Io and luna could have been moons, not MOTHs.  (Of course, Luna would have needed a capital L, so that's why I gave it more thought.)

One little nit, though, for GENEVE:  I'm sure that to signal French, they should have said "de La Suisse."  Or just "suisse." (Adjective.)

I see the "Cat People" (43A) are back today, too.

3D reminds me of that old riddle:  What's the difference between beer nuts and deer nuts?

Beer nuts are $4.99; deer nuts are under a buck.

I'll see myself out.

This was not the Saturday storm some of us were seeking after the very calm Friday. I'm sorry, but this one is barely a Friday challenge from even just two or three years ago. To me, it's a pleasant themeless Wednesday. This is supposed to be The New York Times Crossword; we might as well be IN ROME.
Wham, bam, I was just in the right groove for this one. Beat my Saturday PR by more than a minute!
Hmmm. What day is today?
Easy Friday but nice to see (almost) no crosswordese in the entire puzzle.
I thought "Events at which to release one's inner geek" would be CROSSWORD PUZZLE TOURNAMENTS!
2-DOWN: There is not actually a lake in 'Suisse' called 'Gen√®ve'. What we call Lake Geneva is called Lac L√©man in French.

Enjoyed this one.  Well below my Saturday average but not close to a PB.  Wasted a few minutes at the end looking for my mistake:  I had convinced myself that the Wayans brother was KEENAN and IN ROMA inexplicably seemed plausible.

Fun puzzle, maybe a bit easy for a Saturday but a couple sticking points.  GENEVE vs GENEVA.  Then having STILL MOVING for a long time over STILL MOOING and having no idea what started with SV for "Higher power".  

I've been to New Orleans 20 times and still somehow needed KR_W__ to think of KREWES.

Then thinking SAYIT instead of SAYST, I think even for old timey speak that's an awkward word.

And of course I knew it was WELL LA DI DAH immediately but there's like five possible spellings of LA DI DAH.

I only looked up like 2-3 answers, I generally only look up proper nouns in areas I have no knowledge in when I have most of the crossing clues already.

Loved this one today‚Äîand I found it at least average Saturday challenge at my current experience level. Even if you found it easy I hope you appreciated some of the fresh clues and entries. I adored STILLMOOING and even once I got the misdirect I had STILLMOVING forever and couldn‚Äôt figure out what SVLAR was (or maybe thought I had DINAR wrong). Also loved SADTROMBONE, ERRANDBOY, NERDFESTS, FEELTHEBURN‚Ä¶ had to jump around a lot. Also liked ONTILT, learning about BEETS  and MOTHs and finally a fresh clue for EVEL (I kept wondering is hog riding a sport I should know about?).
A few other notes:
Yeah we‚Äôve hashed and rehashed DERMA just recently. I get it, it‚Äôs archaic and the editors should have known better this time around but can we just let it go this time?
Poor Toronto, way to rub it in
Poor Orcas, way to rub it in, never any love for creatures just trying to get a meal the way God made them.
SKINCARE, speaking of way to rub it in‚Ä¶

I seem to be odd man out once again among the early solvers.  

I didn't think it was all that easy.  I knew of was being baited with ][Io or luna], but I still had to rip out mOon.  

Nothing was working for me in the NE, and a lot of it hinged on having no gaming knowledge at all, so FORTNITE only came to me as something I'd vaguely heard.  

I'm still perplexed by POLED for [Punted].  Maybe I'll look it up, and maybe I won't.  I'm feeling whimsical tonight.

And a bit THICK.

But you know who I don't think is a bit THICK?   Andrzej.  Right now he is realizing that punishing us for the emus' behavior is like blaming another victim for the crime. 

Juuuuuust sayin'.

Wednesday level difficulty. 

3/10
Re: 50A clue - too soon, too soon!!
I appreciated FEELTHEBURN crossing SUNTAN. Cute detail, especially in a crossword featuring SKINCARE.
Took a few minutes to break in but once I did it flowed nicely. Didn't exactly FEELTHEBURN but I still enjoyed it, got the gold star in 10:15

Hmmm‚Ä¶. Is it Wednesday??
I was looking forward to a nice challenging Saturday with my sashimi and Asahi but apart from MOTH having me stuck on MOON for a bit, it was all a bit disappointing‚Ä¶

Easy Saturday puzzle.  Not a PB but half my average time‚Ä¶

After pestering me endlessly to upgrade my iOS app I find a new end-of-year recap with ads!  Who asked for this?  Really disappointing‚Ä¶.
Got to go against the grain here, this was a real challenge for me today! A good 5 minutes over my average

All the complaints about ‚ÄúWednesday level‚Äù are making me feel a bit THICK.

The top half filled in quickly enough, but I had difficulty in the nether regions. (Dontcha hate it when that happens?) Some of it was wavelength, some of it was ignorance: I had no idea what that silly beard is called, for example. The punted/POLED thing baffled me (hi, Francis!), and I‚Äôve never seen SAYST without an E between the Y and S before. (I reluctantly, and for the same reason, had SAYth there for far too long.)

This wasn‚Äôt the most enjoyable experience for me, but chin(strap) up, there‚Äôs always tomorrow.

Can't believe I finished a Saturday, wow! I'm sure this was considered easy but it was just wonderfully challenging and satisfying to finish without hints.

Love when confusing l and I make a clue look like gibberish for a moment. 

Love a rare pun. 

Love the fact that I went to a karaoke party at a bar during the last game of the world series so I just happened to know that sports answer.

Love that I only know who hosted a rival late night show against Conan, briefly, because they made light of their similar names on a random weeknight that I happened to be awake at 11:45pm to see when I was 12, and for no good reason, stayed in my memory for 27 years. Why do I still think about that...

So SAYYST I.

This was not an easy puzzle for me, as if I had to get into a suit and enter a stage of virtual reality. The tone was unfamiliar, and the when I finally started to feel more comfortable in how the constructor was skewing his clues and the answers started to emerge, I was surprised at how it all started to fall into place.  Weirdly, the code started to crack with SAYST.  Sayst? Well that's what the clue sayst, and it was a stepping stone into the puzzle.

I had a look-up.  There. I've said it.  KREWES was a word I had seen before, but not one I remembered.

Mr. Gard, this was a truly, if unusual, pleasure to work.  Bring more puzzles, please. I would like to work them.

Look, I agree that this was easy for a Saturday ‚Äî not quite a PB for me, but well below my average. With that said, I‚Äôm bewildered at the repeated comment that this is a ‚ÄúWednesday level of difficulty.‚Äù I‚Äôll give you Friday, no question, but Wednesday? Are we solving the same Wednesday puzzles?
UGHHHHHHH!!!

what a strange puzzle.
flew through 80% of the grid like a wednesday and finished with  a nor'easter friday (KREWES, MOTH, ERRANDBOY, e.g.).
too easy by more than half.

I found it a very decent Saturday. Thanks to the providers. Thanks @Barry Ancona for stomping on any Œ¥Œ≠œÅŒºŒ± discussion early. 

For those who claim it was easy ‚Ä¶ the puzzle contained a US dog society acronym, the name of a ‚Äòsandwich‚Äô that doesn‚Äôt exist outside the US, the crossing said sandwich with two proper names, a Greek medical term, the name of a video game !!, a clue for ORCA that required knowledge of recent events in the straits of Gibraltar, knowledge of tennis history, baseball trivia, ‚Ä¶. And a misdirection on solar system objects. 

And that‚Äôs not even talking about KREWES 

It wasn‚Äôt easy. Some people are just knowledgeable about all kinds of things üòÄ

This left a bad taste. I started with Edberg as the big Sampras rival, had Haiti as the sugar producer, assumed Mardi Gras societies were Creole, (correctly) put Geneva as the lake, refused to believe we could be doing DERMA again, wrongly stoked fires instead of COALS, then went for antic instead of CAPER, hated ONTILT(?), never heard of KREWES or AKC, didn‚Äôt know about baseball, and balked at the clues for INROME and SADTROMBONE - mistaking ‚ÄúWomp womp‚Äù for ‚ÄúWhoop whoop‚Äù.

Easy? Gimme a break.

I thought it was fun. Growing up on the Gulf Coast I knew what Mardi Gras parade organizers were, and the video game one was a gimme, so I got the top right block pretty fast. 

Top left had me stumped because I didn't get the slang for rare solve until almost the end. Was proud to have figured out the famous hog rider pretty fast though. Folks may also remember him as Marty Funkhouser on Curb Your Enthusiasm, who passed away a bit back. If he looks a bit like Albert Brooks that is because he was his brother (Albert changed his birth name Einstein for obvious professional reasons). OK enough trivia....time to start the two week break over here in Germany (what we call the "time between the years").

I got it without lookups, but it wasn‚Äôt super easy.  Left it a few times and came back, a few letters at a time.  Krewes?  Had fire before coals.  Cree before Erie, and still not sure how PUNTED is POLED.
Wow a Fri and a Sat I enjoyed - challenging but accessible with a few lookups.

This wasn't that easy for me! Yesterday was so full of what I didn't know, that even with crossers, I couldn't finish without looking up a great deal - it happens.

This crossword was more straightforward for me than yesterday,  but still, much that was unfamiliar: KREWES, KENNEN, AKC, TORONTO, CHINSTRAP, ON TILT, FORTNITE. 

STILL MOOING was funny, (I'll use that) and I liked ANTLERS. I thought womp, womp referred to bombs being dropped! I think the sad trombone sound is more of a "wah, wah, wah".

I can't work out DORIS?

Still enjoyable working out the clues I did solve,
As long as we are making reference to Geneva using French nomenclature, "Gen√®ve" does NOT refer to the lake en Suisse. Les Suisses call it "Lac L√©man".

In the discussion of whether an end of week puzzle is too easy or not, I just want to point something out.  Newer solvers are not supposed to be able to solve them.

They are goal to work towards.  

To remain fun for experienced solvers, they have to be impossible for inexperienced ones.

When experienced solvers say a puzzle it too easy, it is in that context. 

It's not an attempt to throw shade or brag.

Another wonderful puzzle this week. Tough in places. Fun answers. Changed things a couple of times just to go back to what I had originally. ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Lower left was tough for me. ANAMISTS was new to me. Overall, a great one. Thanks, Robert! Have a great Saturday, y‚Äôall!
Re. the answer to 50 Across - did you really have to remind me?
Great puzzle

ON TILT has also become a chess term.

One of my sons is a chess player. It's kind of his default activity. In circumstances where a lot of people would be on social media, he will have his phone out to play chess with someone somewhere in the world. He's decent at it; he's ranked somewhat to the right of the middle of the bell curve. Weirdly, he has never played a single game of chess using a physical board, and doesn't particularly want to 

He described to me a game where he was playing someone who was ranked considerably higher than him. My son made a move that blew a hole in his opponent's strategy, causing him to make a series of angry, ill-considered moves. My son won, but he then had to look at the guy text enraged accusations that he'd cheated, because nobody with my son's ranking could possibly have beaten him fairly.

That guy was ON TILT.
Not a complaint, per se, but much easier than a normal Saturday.
A baseball entry I can solve without asking my husband!!! Am I dreaming?!?! ü§£ ü§£ü§£

If the clue had been "Io or Luna" as the puzzle was titled, it would have been even more difficult, but it was actually "Io or luna." ...no capitalization of the final word, so not a reference to our moon.

At one point thought that both words might start with a lower-case "L."

I was only dimly aware of the existence of the game FORTNITE, and I've never heard of an "Io" moth, so it took a lot to get my mind to relinquish its death grip on MOon.

What an amazing and clever misdirect.

Oh, a gorgeously filled 64-worder, a joy to uncover  Look at those 11s: FEEL THE BURN, SAD TROMBONE, STILL MOOING, and WELL LA DI DAH.  Each colorful, and each appearing in the Times puzzle for the first time. And hardly a whiff of junk anywhere.

It takes talent and sweat to fiil a grid like this.

Enough riddles and return-to areas to satisfy my brain‚Äôs work ethic, some ‚ÄúWhee!‚Äù splats, some deep burrows for words I know I‚Äôve known but are hiding, and some feelgood pat-on-the-back moments where a clue that could‚Äôve fooled me didn‚Äôt.

And [Dogsbody].  Now there‚Äôs a word that can mean anything, simply anything, if you don't know it, and I didn't.  That answer mightily fought me, and oh what a sweet feeling to finally win that battle.

I loved the [Bills first introduced in 1861] misdirect, learned CHINSTRAP beard, and the Van Gogh clue prompted a momentary blissful mental revisit of his ‚ÄúThe Starry Night‚Äù.  

Simply a rich and splendid outing, Robert.  Thank you so much for making this!
50 across stung badly. Too soon. Way too soon.

The "too easy" crowd is out in force today.
But it's hard to complain, especially since I'm one of them.
Yet the repetition of the complaints is becoming more than a little tiresome.  
It's nice to hope that the editors peruse these comments, and to hope that they will be interested in "satisfying their base".
On the other hand, they know that we're addicts.  Where are we gonna go?  The LATimes?  WaPo?

That's my complaint about the complaints.
Here's my complaint about the puzzle:
I've heard thousands of TROMBONEs in my life, both SAD and otherwise, but I've never heard one that sounded anything like [womp, womp]!

Oh, poor me!
[Wah, wa-a-a-ah]

Please be patient with me for asking this question, which I know some people don‚Äôt want to hear, and let me make it abundantly clear that I‚Äôm not doing it to annoy anybody, but I do have to ask, lest I forget, in the humblest way I know how, is this the same Gary Larson as Far Side?

Delicious and fun. I loved this puzzle for its variety and the way it let me chip away at the full fill. Every pass I could get at least one more across or down. Fun and satisfying is super rare for a Saturday.
Solved like another themeless Wednesday for me and this time in even less time than Friday. Not what I've been led to expect from a Saturday puzzle.

Well, this one seemed even easier than yesterday's. Saturday personal best for me at 13:54. And I'm *not* a fast solver.

Early Christmas present? Hanukkah gift? 

Other than STILLMOVING before STILLMOOING, don't think I stumbled on much of anything.

Solid puzzle, but the cluing seemed much too direct for a Saturday. Or maybe this one was just in my wheelhouse, since things like MOTH, ANAMISTS, KREWES went in instantly.

I looked at one of this constructor‚Äôs previous puzzles and found it had a ‚Äúclip‚Äù based clue, just as today‚Äôs does (with [Generate clippings, say], for MOW).  

It was a clue I greatly liked, and will share: [Clipper‚Äôs bounty].

(answer in reply)

Unlike other experienced solvers, I didn't find this a particularly easy solve. Too many expressions that I didn't know, such as DOGSBODY, POLED, ON TILT, KREWES, CHINSTRAP, et al. 

But I absolutely loved STILL MOOING, beef limited as I am. REUBEN held me up for a little bit, since I came of age in Kosher deli era, where a slice of cheese could never touch the corned beef. Now they're my favorite things to eat, at pubs, not delis.

So it took me a little longer, but at last got it finished after I realized that I had mistakenly entered CODEd instead of CODER. Finally it all came together without any lookups, and once again I had the satisfaction of completing a puzzle that I thought I would have to abandon.

Great puzz today! I have some advice. If you haven't already, go back and do some Thu/Fri/Sat from the 90s and 00s! There is nothing more satisfying than slaying the puzzles you were to intimidated by when they were initially published! I rem I would just not bother after Tue/Wed....now-a-days, I don't even bother solving until Thu!
A good puzzle is also a trivia challenge, which this one was, though I found it to be on the difficult side, but the right level of difficulty for a Saturday.

For once a bit surprised that most everyone else found this unusually easy. Not that easy for me. More than a couple of complete unknowns (STILLMOOING, SADTROMBONE, KREWES, e.g.), and others that weren't going to dawn on me just from the clues. No big deal. Long workout but overall an enjoyable solve. A couple of puzzle finds today. Here's one - a Wednesday from October 18, 2017 by John Lithgow and Brendan Emmett Quigley. This one was all in the clues. Some examples: "Decision to go with drapes instead of blinds?" CURTAINCALL "Accountant's shares in a company?" SUMMERSTOCK "Fly fisherman?" CASTPARTY "Why one missed the coach?" STAGELEFT Clever that all of those answers were related. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/18/2017&g=10&d=D I'll put the other puzzle in a reply. ....

Really a fun and well crafted puzzle, albeit super easy for a Saturday. Guess I'll hit the archives for my "fix". I've worked my way backwards to 2016, doing Saturday through Thursday in reverse. Those late-week puzzles 9 years ago are often but not universally more challenging IMHO...YMMV. Happy weekend everyone!
Too easy for Saturday
STILLMOOING for the win! (Sorry, vegans...) This puzzle took a lot of head scratching -- really fun. Good job Robert.

SAYST?  I must confess that I prefer puzzles in which the solutions (assuming that the solution is a "real" word as opposed to a rapper's name or a lipstick brand or Greenlandic slang) are actually words to be found in the dictionary.
Well done. Fairly challenging, but there was a path to victory. Zero obscure cop outs. That's how they should all be done. Thank you for your integrity.
This was a fun puzzle.Small mistakes slowed me down. I thought luggage may have an "IR" tag rather than an "ID" tag. Also I was pondering a nerd fair, not fest. Got it eventually.
Smooth but a very pleasant solve and it was nice to be reminded of Diane Keaton (17A).  Also, a clever *mis* for POLED.

Count me in the Hard column. Took 48 mins (compared to a Sat average of 44).But what I realized is that there are different experiences of Hard. There's "I can't get a foothold anywhere" versus "I've got everything but this one pesky corner." The NE for me. Didn't help that I held on to FREE for 22A way too long even though 10D was going to need another vowel in there before RSTS...
Doh! not to see MOW of course. (My spouse almost always does that job. And we certainly never rake up the clippings.)
So I enjoyed this one. And happy to see that our Polish friend is back. Doh! again for not catching on till his second post.
Anyone else do "In Roma" and "Keenan" ?
Thanks for reminding me that MY JAYS lost the World Series! Sigh.
I learned a new word: "dogsbody." Also learned the spelling of "krewes."

Splendid fun way to start a Saturday - thank you! 

But 50A?? Too soon, Mr Gard, too soon... (muffles sobs ü•≤ ...)

Wow....  I lucked out!  CAST PARTY was my first Ping! Entry, and it opened up vast sections of the puzzle.  
Either I was just on Robert Gard's wavelength, or I just lucked into a puzzle that meshed perfectly with my NERDy knowledge bases.  Insects! Art history! Switzerland! Baseball!  Forties/Fifties singers! NOLA! Asimov novels!  And oh! Those Wayans brothers :0)

Just for the record, the *highly-paid* RODEO employees prefer "Bull-fighters" to being referred to as "clowns."  It's a dangerous job, obviously.  Our neighbor in Arkansas had a nephew who stopped by from time to time-- he was "Rockin' Robin"...just following the RODEO circuit in that very role.

The comments today brought to mind the vaguely relevant quote that many people(3) consider the greatest in the history of cinema: 

"I feel the need ... the need for speed!"

                                                          -Tom Krewes

Alt clue that might have been more positive - [Team that in all of recorded history has only lost a single World Series(2025)}

SAD TROMBONE for all the Blue Jays fans out there. Enjoyable puzzle, but at 20 minutes, over far too quickly. Interesting clue for EVEL Knievel, who rode Harley Davidson motorcycles exclusively. Their ticker symbol on the NYSE is HOG, by the way.

Easy for some , harder for me . I had ComicCon instead of Nerd fest for too long , and Moon instead of Moth . I eventually got there . It felt more like a trivia fest for me - scratching my old head to think of Fortnite -LOL .
Too easy for a Saturday -- finished it in much less than half my average Saturday time, which is about my average Wednesday time.

Thank you, Robert, for a very fine, clever grid. I scored my best Saturday time, but really think it's because I was enjoying myself so much. I really loved STILL MOOING and, as a lover of rare beef on rare occasions, shall consider requesting it be prepared that way while dining out.üêÆüòâ

Happy weekend, everyone!
I rarely use the timer as a measure of how easy or hard a puzzle is. That said, this was definitely a cruise to the finish. Well, time to get choring. House doesn‚Äôt clean itself.
TOA-T no clue at all about what that means
TIL a dogsbody is a gofer. Yesterday I learned a diktat is a fiat. This is a good run!
Got stuck on bluejay instead of TORONTO, which slowed me considerably in the SW.

Today was just like yesterday. I finished in about half my average time but have no complaints because it was an enjoyable puzzle, and I don't mind the occasional quick weekend solve instead of the more common nearly impenetrable ones. 

Speaking of impenetrable, this English major spent more time in the Ulysses rabbit hole Ms. Lovinger sent me down than I did solving the puzzle. DOGSBODY leads to "ineluctable modality" leads to a Zen koan leads to Proteus leads the seahorses of Manann√°n leads to the ninth wave and so on ad infinitum...
NW corner was the last to fall. I should have solved 20A sooner, considering my husband arm-wrestled EVEL in a bar in the 80's.

I found today's Saturday offering to be a fine challenge, but in the end, not a killer by any means, but a puzzle that fell in the Goldilocks zone of being just right in every respect.

I did not know the word "dogsbody" or that CHINSTRAP was not only a kind of penguin but also a beard. Loved the clue for STILL MOOING. Had no idea for the clue [womp, womp] until it filled itself in.
I sure bundled this up - so certain HAITI supplied the sugar.
This was so hard WOW!!!!

Tough but fair - it was one of those puzzles that seemed impenetrable at first, but then I found a few down at the bottom and worked my way back up without having to take a break or look anything up. Just about ideal for a Saturday challenge.
I enjoyed this puzzle. Good double meanings to many words. But "dogsbody"? That's a new one to me!

Another late puzzle find: A Sunday from September 4, 2016 by Tom McCoy with the title "One by one." Unusual rebuses in this one, working differently across and down. Some examples: (B&O)RAILROAD - but the down crossing was... EL(BO)WS (R&B)ALBUM - down crossing... MOTO(RB)IKE GETSALITTLE(R&R) - down crossing... NOTTOWO(RR)Y (S&P)FIVEHUNDRED - down crossing... A(SP)ERUSUAL (A&W)ROOTBEER - down crossing... H(AW)KS Some other across theme answers: PEANUT(M&M)S TEXAS(A&M) Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/4/2016&g=93&d=A ...
I would be very happy to never see DERMA defined as a layer of skin for the rest of my life.
Krewe of Muses is an all-female Krewe. This looks like the Krewe of Rolling Elvi.

Have you ever jumped the gun on a few crosses and confidently filled in TROubles instead of TROMBONE and the spent the next 15 minutes lost in the woods?

Well, I did.

Loved it. Lots of crunchy fill and minimal ‚Äúcrossword-ese‚Äù.

STILL MOOING had me questioning until the end; LEWIS before DAY and SUNHAT before SUNTAN.

SADTROMBINE / IRIBOT held me up for a beat at the finish line.

Cheers
Excellent! My journey was pretty much the same as the columnist‚Äôs. STILLMOOING took me back to my steakhouse days. Thanks!
This one threw me off my 3-week streak. The NE did me in with 7D, 10D, & 12D being foreign to me, and I had FreE, Fall, and Fell, but never FIRE. SADTROMBONE!

Okay, with apologies - one of the strangest puzzles I've ever encountered. A Sunday from December 28, 1975 by Frances Hansen with the title: "Aspirin time." Five 23 letter grid-spanning theme entries. Here they are: WEWENTTOAPARTYONNEWYEAR SEVEATQUARTERTOTWOYOUSU GGESTEDWELEAVEIREFUSEDI DETESTBEINGTOLDWHATTODO APOXONTHEPARTYAPOXONYOU Whew. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=12/28/1975&g=55&d=A ....
Still a little confused with "POLED" for Punted???
Either I'm finally getting good at this or the past few Fridays and Saturdays have been really easy.  Under 20 minute solves on those days are very rare and now they happen quite frequently.

Surprised to see so many who had never heard of a dogsbody. I think it‚Äôs British perhaps and I‚Äôve heard it while living there and encountered it in novels.  Also surprised that many thought this was an easy solve.  I will freely admit that I needed lots of help from Caitlin and a few other sources. Saturdays can be like this, and it was definitely tough for me.

I was going to impress my kids with my knowledge of newfangled slang by dropping ‚Äústill mooing‚Äù into a sentence the next time I mention some rarity. 

So glad I read the column and will save myself from being laughed at.

Excellent puzzle!

Oh the joy I felt when I pulled AGASSI out of the bingo ball cage that is my brain! I know he's not exactly obscure, but it's been a long quite a while since I thought about him. I've had bouts of caring about tennis in my life and that was one of them. 

I'm not saying that I'm all hoity toity or anything, but it's just nice to know sometimes that I still got it!  ü§£ 

Don't worry, I'm not getting a big head. I should have gotten BEETS faster because I recently did an impact report on our sugar beets research program for work.

So something I knew about some 35 years ago or so popped out way faster than something I knew about this very year. But that's just how bingo ball cage brains work! ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

What I haven't followed in a very, very, very long time, like since the 1980s Brewers, is baseball. I only knew the answer to 50A because of this crossword comment community. This one was embarrassingly easy for me. Not  only was it my fastest ever Saturday, it was my second fastest solve of the week (after Monday). I am not a speed solver by any means; I just didn't encounter any resistance. Currently working through crosswords from 2011, where late-in-the-week puzzles can take me an hour or more to solve. @Vaer
Part 2

The more words a constructor locks into a puzzle, the fewer options there are moving forward. Each entry that gets placed limits the remaining entries and puts more constraints on the grid. By the time the constructor gets to the final corner, it‚Äôs often difficult to fill that section cleanly. The constructor may have to rip out sections that have already been filled several times before getting something without too many tough vocabulary words or proper nouns crossing.

When I review puzzles with my fellow editors, and especially themeless puzzles, we often note when a particular section is not quite as nice as the rest of the grid. While it‚Äôs not always the case, you can often tell which corner was the last to be filled.

Serious question; I know that "punters" can mean men who frequent prostitutes (I've been watching "Vice" on Prime) but is "punting" common usage for that activity? The clue for POLED made me think of that.

@Grant I think it's river boating - punts are flat -bottomed boats that you propel by pushing a long pole off the stern. You also bring along a picnic to feed your sweetie who is laying decorously in the bottom of the punt. Ideally you don't pole vault into the river and get covered in duck weed. My mum's family had a punt, growing up in Henley on Thames and she adored that boat....

@Grant My friends in the UK use ‚Äúpunters‚Äù as a slang term to mean customers/clients in general. They wouldn‚Äôt use it to someone‚Äôs face, but I‚Äôve definitely had friends talk about dealing with punters at work. (Mostly I‚Äôve heard it from app developers who quite like & respect their clients so I hadn‚Äôt realized any negative connotations.)

@Grant
No, I'm pretty sure it's not used like that.

It's used  for placing a bet - 'have a punt on' and those who do are also 'punters'. 
Punting in the sense of using a flat-bottomed boat, known as a punt, is a rarified activity only really happens at the prestigious Oxford and Cambridge.

Hi, I found this to be particularly difficult and it took me a very long time + reading the wordplay column. Any advice for a newer solver of Saturdays?

@Patil keep at it. Just keep working through the clues one by one, and gradually you should make progress. Open your mind to wordplay -- STILL MOOING is an example of a classic Saturday deception. On Saturdays, puns that might be hinted at with question marks on other days are often presented as if they were "straight" clues.

@Patil I agree with @Dave Munger. Just keep completing all of the days and recognize that the trickiest day (intended to be Saturdays) will have wordplay on many of the clues. As Dave shared, if there's a question mark following a clue, you can be sure that the clue will not be straightforward! Also, take advantage of the crosses to figure out the longer words and review the puzzle once you've completed it so you can see the typical forms of clueing for Saturdays. The wordplay column also provides helpful links such as this one that may help you build up to Saturdays: https://www.nytimes.com/article/how-to-solve-a-crossword-puzzle.html Good Luck -- you'll get there!üòä
Patil ‚Äî a useful suggestion I once learned is to always look everything up that you didn't know in each puzzle, so you'll have a better chance the next time they appear.

@Patil

Get to 1000 solves even if it takes look ups. It starts clicking around then.

@Patil
What others have already said, plus:
Grammar is your friend. Is 'read' present tense or past? Is 'lead' a noun, a verb, or an adjective? If you find a way to wiggle out of the 'obvious' reading, you may end up where you need to be.
Especially late in the week  don't expect every tricky reading to have a "?" signpost.
E.g. "Rail" = COMPLAIN
Here, 'rail' is a verb, not a noun.
"Boxing match" might give you POUNDFORPOUND, although this is almost a British/cryptic clue. I'd be interested in who thinks this would be an unfair clue, even on a Saturday.
@andrew ‚ÄúTo a T‚Äù means "perfectly or precisely"
@andrew When you get something perfectly right, you do it "to a tee."
For instance, a perfectly cooked menu item might be said to be "done to a T".
How'd that work out for him?
PS But the answer LA-DI-DAH seemed to have a very unusual choice of spelling: the one-H-at-the-end version. (Typically I've seen either LAH-DIH-DAH or LA-DI-DA, but not LA-DI-DAH.)
Dan, In the crossword, especially on Saturday, expect a valid but less common spelling. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/la-di-da
